transcript:
Patient: The main challenge I've faced with setting aside time for painting is that I feel guilty for taking time away from work. Even when I do manage to paint, I find it hard to fully relax and enjoy the process because I'm thinking about all the tasks I could be completing instead.

Therapist: It's common for people who struggle with perfectionism and high standards to feel guilty about taking time for themselves. This guilt often stems from the belief that your worth is tied to your productivity or achievements. Let's explore this belief further.

Can you think of any potential negative consequences of not allowing yourself time to relax and engage in activities you enjoy?

Patient: Well, I know that constantly working without breaks leads to burnout and increased stress levels. It can also strain relationships with loved ones if I'm always prioritizing work over spending time with them.

Therapist: Exactly. Neglecting self-care and personal fulfillment can have significant negative impacts on your mental health, relationships, and overall quality of life. It's important to recognize that taking time for yourself is not selfish or unproductive. In fact, it's essential for maintaining balance and preventing burnout.

One technique we can use to help you prioritize self-care is called "scheduled relaxation." This involves intentionally scheduling time for activities you enjoy, just as you would schedule work tasks or appointments. By treating self-care as equally important and non-negotiable, you can start to shift your perspective and reduce feelings of guilt.

Let's practice this now. Can you think of a specific time this week when you could schedule a painting session or another self-care activity?

Patient: I could schedule a painting session on Thursday evening, after work. I usually stay late at the office on Thursdays, but I could try to leave on time and dedicate that evening to painting.

Therapist: That's a great plan, Priya. Scheduling your painting session after work on Thursday will allow you to unwind and transition out of work mode. It's important to communicate your boundaries with your colleagues and let them know that you will be unavailable during that time.

As you engage in your scheduled relaxation, try to practice being fully present and mindful. Notice any thoughts or feelings that arise, but gently redirect your focus back to the activity at hand. If you find yourself feeling guilty or thinking about work, remind yourself that this time is essential for your well-being and that you are allowed to prioritize your own needs.

Patient: I like the idea of scheduled relaxation. It makes self-care feel more structured and purposeful. I'll try to communicate my boundaries with my colleagues and remind myself that taking time for painting is important for my mental health.

Therapist: I'm glad you find the concept of scheduled relaxation helpful, Priya. Remember, it may take some practice to fully embrace this new mindset, but with time and consistency, it will become easier to prioritize self-care without guilt.

As you continue to work on challenging perfectionism and setting boundaries, it's also important to address any underlying beliefs that may be contributing to these patterns. In our next session, we can explore some of these deeper beliefs and work on reframing them in a more balanced and compassionate way.

For now, let's focus on implementing the techniques we've discussed today. In addition to scheduling relaxation, continue practicing the "double standard" technique and actively looking for evidence that contradicts your negative thoughts. Remember to bring your thought records to our next session so we can review your progress and discuss any challenges that arise.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate your guidance and support. I'll do my best to implement these techniques and bring my thought records to our next session. I'm looking forward to exploring my underlying beliefs further and continuing to work on challenging perfectionism.
